div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE "EGYPTIAN STANDARD."
div.p: We were recently compelled to express our opinions re the accusations made by "Al Lowa" and its European editions with some vigour, We were not surprised when a few days later a notice large type appropriately labelled "Falsehood," and appearing in the "Egyptian Standard," accused the "Egyptian Gazette" of wilful misstatements, and declared that Mustaplia Pasha's organs had merely reproduced a communication from the Omdeh of Warrak and had in no way accused M. Grandmoulin of wilful murder. Sunday's "Egyptian Standard" contains an article from Mustapha Pasha Kamel, who asseverates that he and his journals have never made any such statement and challenges the Press--or rather that section of the Press which has refused to accept the "ipse dixit" of our new prophet as being final in all matters to prove its assertion. We are ready, nay more, we are delighted, to take up the gauntlet which the Pasha has thrown down. In the "Egyptian Standard" of March 12 an article, entitled "A Victim of Pigeon Shooting," was published by our contemporary. It contained the account of the accident as given by the Omdeh of Warrak and concluded with the remark that the French Consulate must make a thorough | and impartial enquiry "so that people may understand that Egyptians cannot be hunted as I game with impunity." On the following day an article appeared on the third page of the "Egyptian Standard." It contained no mention of the Omdeh of Warrak. After remarking that the affair had cause a painful sensation the writer of this article remarked that "we" looked at the whole incident from an "impartial point of view," but that the fact was that M. Grandmoulin had shot a child either voluntarily or involuntarily. After this excursion into the realms of the obvious and certain "remarks anent the question of trespass, the article closes with two questions, which we I give as they appear in our lurid contemporary "We wish......to ask the following pertinent questions."
"1) What right had M Grandmoulin to shoot on land not his property?
"2) How is it possible that M. Grandmoulin still keeps his Government employ accused and guilty as he is of assassination?"

We therefore reply to Mustapha Pasha Kamel that in accusing us of wilful falsehood and in declaring that no accusation has been made against M. Grandmoulin in his organs, he is not speaking the truth or anything near the truth. His statements are as false as they are malicious, and when we think that their author is regarded as a leader by certain Nationalists, we are tempted to remark with the Anglo-French diplomatists in "The Modern Traveller :"
"If such a man as that," said they,
"Is leader, they may go their way."

There is one alternative explanation which we offer in the hope that Mustapha Pasha Kamel's reputation for integrity may thereby be rescued (at the cost of his reputation for possessing any write whatever). It is this - that neither Mustapha Pasha nor his gladiators know enough English to be aware that the word "assassination" is not used of accidental homicide, and that they are sufficiently unintelligent not to see that the effect of their phrases concerning impartiality is spoiled by the use of a term employed in the description of wilful murder. In this case we should recommend our critic to take a course of elementary lessons in English and the rules of logic. But if, as we fear, our first hypothesis —that a deliberate falsehood has appeared in the "Egyptian Standard"--be correct, we can only inform the Nationalist leader that we have answered his challenge and that we throw back in his teeth his accusation of lying.

div.head: Berber show.
div.p: The annual agricultural and industrial show for the Berber province will be held this year at Damir on Friday, 13th April.

div.head: New Telegraph Line.
div.p: The Sudan Telegraph Department has decided to create a new telegraphic line between Assouan and Wady Halfa. The cost of the undertaking is estimated at L.E. 1,500.

div.head: "AI Moayad."
div.p: The head of the War Office Intelligence Department has informed the manager of "Al Moayad" that the entry of that newspaper into the Sudan is henceforth to be prohibited.

div.head: Vitality Statletios.
div.p: The Board of Health is drawing up a new law for the registration of births and deaths. This law will be submitted to the Mixed Appeal Court in order to make it applicable to Europeans as well as natives.

div.head: Native Judges.
div.p: The official monthly salaries of the native bench under the new law will henceforth be as follows for the five different classes of judges : 1, LE. 45. 2, LE. 40. 3, L.E. 35 4, LE. 30. 5, L.E. 25.

div.head: Sport on White Nlle.
div.p: Three football clubs have been organised at Wad Medani. One is annexed to the "Mudiria Club, another draws its members in from the 13th Battalion, and the third from the Government school.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin records a fresh case and a death at Beni Mazar, a case at Mellawi, a case and a recovery at Deirout, a Case, and a recovery at Baharia, a fatal case at Keneh, two fatal cases at Deshneh, a death at Sohag, and a recovery at Esneh.

div.head: Big Specle Dargo.
div.p: The P. and 0.S.S. Namur, which is due at Port Said, carries the following specie for Colombo : Bar gold, £7,500 ; coin gold, £1,000; and bar silver, £2,500; and for Calc. ttá, bar gold, £45,000; bar silver, £203,300; and Calo itta dollars, silver, £128,400 - total, £387,700.

div.head: The Suez Route.
div.p: Owing to the irregularities of the San Francisco mail service, the New Zealand Government has directed that no mails to or from Great Britain shall be sent or received by that route for the present The Suez route will be u-ed until further notice, with the direct and Vancouver lines as auxiliaries.

div.head: Sale of Land.
div.p: We would draw the attention of those of our I readers who are interested in land to the sale of several plots of building land at Delingat, an important centre and market town in the Behera. The land belongs to the Delta Light Railway Company, and further particulars will be found in our advertising columns.

div.head: Accident to Governor of Calro.
div.p: Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Cairo, was driving in his carriage across a tram line near Kasr el-Aini, Cairo, on Sunday last, when the carriage collided with a tramcar, the former being overturned and smashed to pieces Fortunately his Excellency managed to jump out of his carriage in time, but in doing so he received somewhat serious injuries.

div.head: Victoria College.
div.p: On Friday last, the Earl and Countess of Meath paid a visit to Victoria College. Lord Meath, after reviewing the boys at drill, delivered a short addregn in which he congratulated Mr. Mustard and the other officers of the three companies on the good work done, and impressed upon the boys the necessity of cultivating the sense of responsibility and public spirit. This is the fourth occasion on which his lordship, whose interest in boys' brigades is well known, has inspected the pupils of Victoria College.

div.head:
THE ROYAL VISIT.
DUKE OF CONNAUGHT'S MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Duke and Duchess of Connaught are to embark here on Thursday next on the S.S. Hardinge for Aden, whence their Royal Highnesses will proceed to Suez on their way to Cairo. After their stay in the Egyptian capital they will finally join the steamer Marmora at Port Said for passage to England.
According to a native contemporary, the Khedive will give a banquet at Abdeen Palace on the 4st proxo. in honor of T.R.H. the Duke and Duchess of Connaught.

div.head: PRINCE FUSHIMI'S MISSION.
div.p: The P. and O. steamer Britannia, which passed through Port Said yesterday on her way bonde, has on board his Imperial Highness General Prince Fushimi, Special Envoy to the Court of St. James's, who is on his way to return the courtesy of the Garter Mission to the Mikado.

div.head: THE GRANDMOULIN AFFAIR.
div.p: M. Grandmoulin has asked the Parquet Generale to take proceedings against Mustapha Pasha Kamel for libelling him in connection with the death of the native boy at Warrak.

div.head: SPORTSMEN AND FARMERS.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has issued the following notice. :--
"The Ministry of the Interior wishes to draw the attention of sportsmen to the serious loss which is caused to cultivators by their entry upon lands under cultivation.

"Their attention is further drawn to the fact that such entry, otherwise than with the permission of the occupier, constitutes an offence within the meaning of Art 334 of the Mixed Penal Code and Art. 340 of the Native Penal Code."

div.head: MR. VERSCHOYLE'S FUNERAL.
div.p: The funeral of Mr. Verschoyle took place this morning at Cairo. The first part of the funeral service was held at 10 o'clock at All Saints' Church. The service was largely attended by the miny friends of the deceased, among them being many of his native colleagues in the Ministry of Public Works. The bier was then conveyed to the cemetery at Old Cairo, where the concluding portion of the burial service took place, over 100 persons being present in the cemetery. Among those who attended the funeral were Lord and Lady Cromer, Mr. Mansfield de C.Findlay, C.M.G, the Minister of Public Works, Sir Wm. Garstin, and nearly all the officials of the - Ministry, several of the Advisers and heads of departments of the other Ministries, and Dm:ny of the personal friends of the late Mr. Verschevyle.

We need not say that the Irrigation Department has suffered a great loss by Mr Verschuyle's death. It is generally felt that a man of his wide technical knowledge and high administrative capacities cannot very easily be replaced. His relations with his juniors, both European and Egyptian, were always excellent, for he possessed ready sympathy and tact, and was always anxious to do everything in his power to aid young officials who gave proof of character and intelligence.

div.head: SUCCESSFUL BAZAAR.
div.p: The Bazaar at the Continental Hotel on Saturday in aid of the funds for "L'Amie de la Jeune Fille," resulted in the taking of some 3,000 francs, no small sum when one realizes how very few weeks the scheme has been in working. Mme Villfurth has been the chief instrument in the shaping of the scheme, sand to her energies, much of the success of the bazaar is due. Many thanks, too, are due to those who so generously gave such substantial donations and gifts to the undertaking, and especially to G. Nungovich Bey and to Mr. Braun, of the Continental Hotel, who kindly placed the big drawing-room at the disposition of the committee and supplied the excellent buffet.

Lady Cromer arrived early in the afternoon to open the bazaar, Mme Viuforth's little daughter presenting her with a bouquet at the door, and she made several purchases from the various stalls. There was a very fair attendance later on, and people spent freely in the cause. Many and varied were the things on sale, some of the lingerie being exceptionally good, and the stalls devoted to toys and dolls were in great request. A brisk business was done at the flower stall, the energetic lady in possession netting in some cases 10s and 15s. for-a tiny buttonhole.

It is hoped that the proceeds of the bazaar in addition to the funds already collected will prove sufficient to establish the Cairo branch of this society on a firm basis ; and that those who are already interested in the soleme may have the satisfaction of seeing it develop into a real help and boon to the friendless girls and women in Cairo.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA AND CYRENAICA.
A NEW STEAMSHIP LINE.
div.p: Egypt has hitherto been without direct and regular communication by sea with Cyrenaica, and we are glad to hear that the enterprise of the Florio-Rubattino Company will soon remedy this want. The steamers of the new line, which the Italian Navigation Company will shortly start, will call at Syracuse, Malta, Tripoli, Misrata, Benghazi, Dermah, Alexandria; Canea, and on the return voyage will proceed to Dermah, Benghazi, Tripoli, Malta, Syracuse, and other Sicilian porta.

There will be four or five steamers on the new line, of about 8,000 tons each, and the departures will take place every fortnight. The company has come to an agreement with the Italian Government on the arrangement for this new service. There will be a regular mail service between the ports of call. - It is expected that a large amount of cattle and cereals will by this means find their way froni Cyrenaica to Alexandria. There will also be a considerable pilgrim traffic during the pilgrimage season.
The formal approbation of the Italian Parliament to the scheme will be given in all probability in May or June, and the regular sailings will begin immediately afterwards.

Cyrenaica used to be one of the most flourishing Greek colonies on the South Coast of the Mediterranean, and even under the blighting influence of centuries of Turkish misrule it is still a beautiful country and full of interesting remains of its former prosperity. Barley, dates, olives, oranges, lemons and vegetables reproduced, and the principal imports are metals, British and or her European manufactures, tea, beads, wine and spirits, besides a number of articles for barter in Wadai, Bornu, and the Western Sidan, whither caravans proceed from Tripoli ; but the caravan trade, onde the mainstay of the country, has seriously diminished of late years The principal articles of exporting are ostrich feathers, ivory, skins, sponges, hides, esparto grass, cattle, and horses. The ancient ruins in Cyrenaica, i.e., at Cyrene Ptolemais, and Apollonia, are interesting to explorers, as well as those at Leptis Magna, which is close to Khoms, or 70 miles from the city of Tripoli ; agricultural colonies of Cretan Moslem refugees are being formed in the neighbourhood. The town of Benghazi has a population of about 15,000, consisting of Arabs, Greeks, Maltese, and a few Levantines. The commerce in cereals, wool, cattle for Malta, and other agricultural produce, is considerable, when a sufficient rainfall causes good harvests.

div.head: ANGIO EGYPTIAN LAND ALLOTMENT CO.
div.p: We understand that the first annual report of the Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Co., which is now being prepared at the head office of the company, will prove an agreeable surprise to the shareholders The company's agricultural business in Cyprus has developed greatly during the past year, and it is no exaggeration to say that the actual value of a considerable part of the properties of the company may be estimated at 40 to 60 % abo e the values indicated in the balance-sheet. The work of the Agricultural Bank of Cyprus is progressing beyond all. expectations. In the three months of 1907 more than three times as many applications for mortgage loans have been received than in the past year.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Busiris arrived in England on Sunday.

div.head:
THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY.
PRESS AND COPTIC PROTEST,
div.p: The stupefaction of the Nationalists at the Coptic protest to Lord Cromer against the General Assembly's proposals is immense. A correspondent of "Al Minbar" declares that when he first heard of it he believed that it was a mere invention of the " Egyptian Gazette, " but now he declares he is certain that the original idea came from Lord Cromer, who suggested the protest to a Coptic notable ! Our French Cairo contemporary, the "Journal du Caire," comments on the protest as follows : --

La gravité d'un pareil acte est immense, si lon veut songer que la prospérité, et l'avenir de l'Egypte exigent impérieusement la bonne exigent et l'accord parfait entre les musulmans et les coptes. Cette gravité n'a échappé à personne ; aussi la requête en question fait-elle actuellement les frais de toutes les conversations et se trouve-t-elle vivement commentée par une partie de la presse indigène et critiguide de façon acerbe par certains coptes.
The "Egyptian Standard" is incensed because our Greek contemporary, the "Phare d'Alexandrie," refuses to concur with the "General Assembly's" extravagances and remarks.

It says: "Le Phare d'Alexandrie" adds its voice to the clamour raised against the Egyptian people. It is strange that a Greek such as M. John Haicalis can so despise Egyptian patriotism when he must be aware of the great influence played by the patriotic idea in the fortunes of his own country. We, ask him the pertinent question why it was that the late Haicalis Pasha was of, opinion, many years ago, that Egypt was ripe for independence. What has occurred to render the country less unfit for this measure?

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE.
div.p: The imports during last month amounted to L.E. 1,958,788, an increase of L.E. 335,733 on the total for the corresponding month last year.
The exports during February amounted to L.E. 2,846,349, an increase of L.E. 470,398' on the total for the previous February.

div.head: CONCERT AT BRITISH CLUB.
div.p: On Saturday last the members of the British Club and their lady friends were again invited to a concert (this being the third which has been given this year) and a very pleasant evening was spent. Mr. E. B. Gould, I.S.O., II. BM Consul-General, and vice-president of the club, was present with Mrs. Gould Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, the other vice-president, was unable to attend, but Lady Hlomfield was present. The concert-room was, it possible, more crowded than on the last occasion.

The opening item on the programme was a quartette given by the "Osiris Glee Party" and entitled "Oh! who will o'er the downs 80 free " This was followed by "Love, could I only tell thee," sung by Mr. Harald Sheldrick, and accompanied by Mrs. Sheldrick'; he was in good voice and afforded general pleasure Mrs Fdward Mogs came next and she captivated the audience with her songs, "My Treasure" and "Philosophy," her voice being remarkable for its sweetness and expression. An encore E veg insisted upon and for this she sang "Annie Jaurie"; her accompaniments were played by Mrs A R. Brown The next item was given by - an old favourite, Mr F M, Dodwell, who rendered "The Chancellor's Dream" from "Iolanthe," in his well-known style. For an encore he recited "Something Original," which was very laughable After this we were favoured with a pianoforte solo by Miss B Cohu, entitled "Le Jet d'eau." Miss Cohu has a capable command over the keyboard and at once secured the goodwill of her listeners by her delicate and refined playing. This was followed by a comic song called "Queer Questions," sung by Mr. Q.H Nicholls, which proved to be very funny indeed and gave those present plenty of cause for a good laugh Mr and Mrs. W.F. Sarjeant were both down on the programme to sing, but Mrs. Sarjeant being unwell we were unfortunately deprived of the pleasure of hearing them. Mr J. B. Clarke, kindly consented to sing in the place of Mrs. Sarjeant, and soon sang himself into the graces of his audience by his rendering of "The Song of the Bow," which concluded the first part of the programme.

The second half comprised the following: Quartette, "On the Banks of Allan Water," Osiris Glee Party ; encore, "Sweet and Low"; song, "Oh Memory," Mr. F. M. Dodwell ; encores, recitations entitled "The Irish Fire Brigade" and "The Pluckiest Deed I ever Did; song, "When dull care," Mr. J. B Clarke: encore, "The Jolly Sailor"; song, "Sunbeam," Mrs. Edward Moss ; encore, "Obstination"; comic song, "Adverts," Mr. O H Nicholls ; Fencore, "My Inquisitive. Kiddie"; the final item being a domestic sketch entitled "Lord and Lady Purplesang," given by Mr. and Mrs Goodrick, which was very amusing.

A word of praise is due to the members of the Entertainment Committee of the club for their enterprise in getting up these high-class entertainments, especially as a lot of the talent secured is quite new to Alexandria. Such success has attended their efforts that the concerts will now be a regular feature throughout the winter season, and we understand that a series of amateur theatrical entertainments will probably be arranged on a small scale, provided sufficient members and their lady friends are found willing to take part in them.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsble for the opinions expressed by our corespoundents, but we wish, in spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain neccessary limits- free discussion

div.head: CRUELTY AT HELOUAN.
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir, — Amongst the events in yesterday's races at Helouan was a two-mile camel race After the first mile, and when opposite the grand-gʻand, one camel, being completely exhausted, lay down. The rider, helped by the native mob, including two policemen, by dint of flogging, made it rise. This happened three times, the poor animal, each time it rose, struggling a few paces forward and lying down until forced to rise by dint of flogging with sticks and kourbashes It was uttering piteous groans, foaming at the month, bleeding from a cut on each flank, besides displaying other symptoms (which I need not mention) of nervous and physical exhaustion After the animal lay down the third time, the rider was forced to dismount and the camel was brought into the paddock. Such a disgraceful exhibition of wilful cruelty to a dumb animal I have not seen before in any part of the world. It seems to me that such exhibitions do not raise the standard of sport. I therefore venture to appeal to you, in the interests of dumb animals, for your support to prevent a repetition of such inhuman scenes, at least before a European crowd composed largely of Britishers. This unfortunate camel being about 400 yards behind the other competitors had no chance of winning the race. Flogging it was consequently quite useless. - I am, ete,
div.byline: B. W. SOMERVILLE-LARGE, FR.C.S.E. (Lt. Col. Retired pay) -
div.dateline: Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helouan, Cairo, Saturday.

div.head: L'Assembly Generale
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur de l'"Egyptian Gazette". Je vous serais bien obligé si vous vouliez bien insérer dans votre journal les quelques lignes qui suivent auxquelles votre impartialité ne refugera certainewent pas la place. 1. J'ai lu dans les colonnes de "l'Egyptian Gizette," que quelques personnes qui se disent Coptes ont présenté à l'Agence Britannique une pétition pour exprimer leurs regrets à l'endroit des décisions prises a mois de Février pas é par l'assemblée Générale. T Or l'Assemblée Gén- rale représente toute la nation Egyptienne. Elle a par conséquent nécessairement exprimé les vœux de tous les Egyptiens, les Coptes aussi bien que les autres. Les pers:nnes qui osent désavouer l'œuvre | mjestueuse accomplie parl s députations égyp tienner ne peuvent donc avoir aucune qualité | pour représenter . tout ou partie de la Nation. En Egypte, comme partout ailleur, les éléments de la Nation forment uue seule et même unite indivisible dont le sort a toujours été et doit toujours être le même. Tous les efforts coupables prodigués pour créer la scission au sein de la pauvre Egypte resteront dono toujours, espérons-le, inutiles et infruc tueux. | C'est, en effet, grâce à des démarches ina vouées que les signataires de la p tition ont consenti à apposer lenrs signatures. 1. Ils ont tous certainement été attirés par des proniesses flatteuses ou obligés de signer par complaisance Le fait même dénote d'aille rs qu'ils n'ont aucune connaissance des institutions sociales modernes. Le moindre notion de ces institutions indique que l'Assemblée Générale, dans ses délibérations et décisions, les a représentés, comme elle a représenté tout le monde égyption ; qu'il ne s'agit point en la matière de coptes ou mahometang, mais d'Egypte et d'Egyptiens ; que ce sont les pétitionnaires eux-mêmes qui, par le rs agissements suscitent, au sein de la nation, la division qu'ils ont toujours vouln éviter. Les signatuires les plus en vue sont d'ailleurs des protégés des autres nations qui ne sont nullement intéressés directement au sort de l'administration et de la Justice locales. En tous cas, la fleur de la communauté copte et la jeunesse instruite se révoltent contre cet acte incorreot et déloyal. Nous en sommes tous vivement indignés. Nous protestons énergiquement contre cette représentation forcée et indigne de nous. Quelques signat ires ramassés dans la rue ou autrement par des promoteurs intéressés ne peuvent en "aucune façon former une représentation copte Je ne vois d'ailleurs pas en quel honneur ou pour quel motif ces messieurs s'intitulent coptea. Nous déanvouons complètement, et la quallté de ces personnes, et leurs meuées. Nous adhérons au contraire pleinement en notre qualité d'Egyptiens et de bons patriotes, aux væux formés par l'Assemblée Générale et souhaitons de toute notro ame que ces vo x soient réalis 8 au plus vite. L'Egyptien, quel q 'il soit, qui s'oppose à la propagation de l'instruction, 2, la diffusion de la science, aux réformes utiles des impôts et de l'administration, à la constitution d'une députation nationale régulière et bien armée, ne mérite pas ce nom. | Nous tenons donc à ce qu'on sache que nous applaudissons, de toutes nos forces, à ces vœux et à ces réformes sollicités et que les | protestations voulues ou ino onscientes, et en to a cas wal fondées de quelques personnes. isol es, peu courageuses et nullement q alifiées ne peuvent être considérées en aucune façon comme une manifestation de la volonté des Egyptiens ou d'une partie de la nation égyptienne. Bien à vous !

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Mohamed Aly, brother of the Khédive, paid a visit two days ago to the Nasrieh and the Normal School, Cairo, where he was received by the Minister of Education and the headmasters and staffs of both schools. His Highness promised to visit the Sanieh girls' school to-day.

On Sunday Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, the Prince Minister, paid a visit to that beautiful part of the Fayoum known as the Egyptian Switzertlnd Yesterday morning his Excellency and the Moudir went to Atosa and Nazleh In the afternoon he left for Cairo. On Monday Bagsal Bey, the great Bedouin chief, was received in audience by his Excellency.
Prince de Polignac and Comte de Bourbon were among the passengers who arrived from Marseilles to-day by the SS. Portugal
The Patriarch of Alexandria, on his way back to Egypt, stopped at Shendi, where he was the guest of Mr Victor Skyrianides.
Prince Mirza, Daniche Khan Afaa ElDowleh, Persian Ambassador at Constantinople, is coming to Egypt shortly.

The engagement is announced of Ir. James Finch, manager of Sir Ernest Cassel's property at Assouan, and Miss Adèle Duncan, second daughter of Mr A Duncan of Knossington Grange, Oakham. Mr. Finch is a son of Mr. H, R. Finch, of the Croft, Oakham.

Colonel Henry Watterson is spending the winter in Egypt, whence he has been sending home some characteristic letters to the "Courier-Journal" in Louisville. A new and enlarged edition of Colonel Watterson's book, "The Compromises of Life," has lately been issued by Duffield & Co. of New York.
Bimbashi Poole, Assistant Director of Intelligence, left Khartoum last week for Wad Medani on an important mission.

Mr. Joseph Comas, technical engineer to the Nile Graving Slip and Shipbuilding Yard, who has had 25 years' experience as marine chief engineer, has been nominated surveyor expert to the Mixed Tribunals of Alexandria, Our congratulations.

150 of the Suevic's passengers have been Saved. The work of rescue continues. There are 160 children on board, and the crew are bringing them ashore in their arms. A high wind has cleared away the fog. Three compartments of the vessel are flooded. The salvage depends upon the weather, which is most unpromising

The West African S.S. Jebba is ashore at Prawle Point. Seventy of the passengers, mostly soldiers and invalids, have been saved by means of the rocket apparatus. The vessel is likely to become a total loss.
Later, The Jebba is a total, loss. The passengers and crow have been saved. The cargo, consisting largely of gold and rubber, is valued at £200,000.
Later, There is some hope of floating the Suevic, All on board have been saved.
Vessels are ashore all along the Channel coast, including large steamers from Dungeness, Cuckmere, Rye, and two from Dover, besides many sailing vessels, (Reuter)
The losses reported at Lloyd's yesterday aggregate £1,500,000; that of the Suevic alone amounting to £500,000. (Reuter)
The King and Queen, on board the Royal yacht, will pay an official visit to King Alfonso at Cartagena early in April. (Reuter)
It is officially stated that only a few dozen Cossacks have been sent to Persia to strengthen the guards of the Consulates. (Reuter)
The Grand Vizier has resigned. (Reuter)
The chemist Berthelot has died on learning - that his wife was dead, (Haras)
Five thousand seamstresses on strike made.a demonstration in the Ringstrasse. They were dispersed by the police. (Havas)

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT
div.p: The "Egyptian Standard " is very annoyed that the London newspapers do not publish the futile questions on Egyptian affairs which are asked in the House of Commons by a few Radical members. It remarks :

"It is strange that this gag should have been got up in London where evidently it is the intention to banish the Egyptian question from the columns of even the most Liberal papers, thus preventing the echo of Lord Cromer's misruler reaching the ears of the British public.
"We shall of course do our best to defraud the hopes of those who wish the truth to remain unknown and publish the account of the Parliamentary questions as taken from the Arabic paper "Ai Minbar.'"

div.head: FROM CAPE TO CAIRO.
WHISKY AND SODA IN A NATIVE CHIEF'S TENT.
AN EIGHT MONTHS' TRAMP.
div.p: Mr A. F. Bory, a Swiss gentleman, has arrived in Cairo from the Cape, having travelled overland.

The interest of this journey of eight months through the very heart of Africa lies in its uneventful character, which testifies to the extraordinary advance of civilization and the facilities of travel in the remote regions traversed.

At Karonga, on Lake Nyassa, began really the first part of the journey away from civilization. The Stevenson road is about 220 miles in length, and runs across the Tanganyika Plateau from the north of Lake Nyassa to the south of Lake Tanganyika, and it takes about a fortnight to traverse. Mr. Bory says:

"Thanks to the courtesy of the German officials, I was allowed to cross the territory from Usambara to Bukoba, a route which is -really closed to caravans. This part of the journey was the most interesting of the whole trip, as the country is still perfectly new. It took me 26 days along native tracks to reach Bukoba, on Victoria Nyanza, the distance being about 328 miles, and during this time I only saw white people three times for the first ten days I did not see any natives, as they used to run away on the approach of the caravan, taking with them everything they. possessed. I then entered the Urundi country, which offers beautiful scenery. The Burundi are very tall and slim, and have perfect features-good nose and lips – a great contrast with the usual negro type. They are, however, of a very dark complexion They wear gweeping garments of bark cloth and necklaces of beads and carved amulets, and generally a very heavy wooden or ivory bracelet on their left. Forearm.

"I stopped for a day at Kanazi, a very pretty place overlooking the Victoria Nyanza and several islands The Sultan of Kanazi is a very important man in the country Five years ago he was dressed in skins and lived in a very rough hus. Now he has a substantial European house and is dressed in a kind of uniform. He received me in this house and offered me some whisky and soda. The Germany told me this change was due to the Uganda railway, which has brought civilization so near. Next day I reached Bukoba, the German military station on the Victoria Nyanza. Having obtained four of the Sultan's canoes I left for Entebbe in Uganda, and those days spent on the lake in native canoes made of planks sewn together with reeds and grass were a very curious experience. The natives usually sing whilst paddling the boat, and some of their songs are not without charm, though they always have a mournful strain.

"From Entebbe to Gondokoro I was again on a trade route, I avoided the Nile on account of the many mosquitoes, and kept to the old inland road Game was very plentiful and antelopes seemed to be quite fearless of the caravan.

"Thus.I concluded my trip from South Africa to Egypt, which lasted eight months from the time I landed at Dürban to my arrival in Cairo. The actual journey across Central Africa from Chinde, at the mouth of the Zambesi, to Gondokoro on the Nile occupied six months, three of which I spent in tents, having covered 1,000 miles on foot. The trip did not entail any serious hardship or danger, my worst enemies being occasional bad water mosquitoes, and fever. I did not come across any wild beasts, although I heard the roaring of lions several times."
(Reuter's Cairo Correspondent).

div.head: EGYPT AND SUDAN MINING SYNDICATE
div.p: The expenditure during the past twelve months in connection with the properties in Egypt and the Sudan was £9,839. At Sept. 30, 1905, the profit and loss account showed a balance of £19,090; from that has been deducted depreciation of buildings, machinery, and plant, & co., leaving to be brought into the current year's account £18,483. The effect of an arrangement entered into with the Suakin Mining Syndicate is to relieve this, the Egypt and Sudan Syndicate, temporarily,of all outlay upon the Barrahine Mine while retaining in it an interest to the extent of 70 per cent.

div.head: EGYPT'S EXPORTS.
GUM ARABIC.
div.p: In view of the fact that gum arabic forms one of the more important of the minor exports from Egypt, we think a few remarks on the trade itself, and the methods of handling the raw products, may possibly be of some interest."

The gum arabic exports for the last six years show the fall in the selling price during the period in question. In 1901 the average price per kilo was nearly 38 milliemes. (8 d), whilst 1 st year this figure dropped to 20 milliemes (5d). The yield, too, in 1906 wes the lowest since 1901.

It is perhaps unnecessary to state that the gum is really the sap from a special kind of tree, which grows from 3 to 5 yards in height, whole forests of which are found in the Kordofan Province and also near Gedid in the White Nile Province The natives are free to collect the gum, the only tax being a royalty levied at Omdurman. This royalty, which last year was about PT. 12 2 6 a cantar (991bs.), varice according to the market price of the gum, and is fixed annually by the Sudan Government.

The seasons during which the trees yield their sap runs from December to May Prior to gathering the " crop," the natives prepare the trees by slightly cutting the bark in numerous places. The gap then exudes, solidifies in the shape of large and small lumps, and is afterwards gathered by hand, such gathering being done before the rainy season commences.

There are two main classes of gum, viz., Ambery and Bleached. In the latter case, the gum is merely exposed to the strong action of the sun generally in Omdurman -- whilst in the former instance it is allowed to retain its natural amber colour..

The best gum, and the largest crop, comes from Kordofan, an inferior quality being found in the Ghezireh Province. Very little of the latter, however, is handled by the European merchants, as there is practically no market for it, abroad. The bulk of the Kordofan ambery gum is sold abroad in tgurts," which is the technical name for the raw product as delivered from the forests by the natives The amount of grading done in Egypt and the Sudan is gradually becoming less and less, as the foreign buyer prefers to do this work himself. If done on this side, the sorting is usually done by native girls at either Omdurman, Cairo, or Alexandria.

After being collected, the gum is taken to the villages - principally Dueim and there sold by the native to the Sudanese brokers for cash. The goods are then forwarded by boat to Omdurman-which is the principal gum market in the Sudan-where they are repacked for markets in strong double sacks holding about 300 lbs. Instead of calculating the usual 100 rotolis (99 lbs) to the cantar, the merchants at Omdurman receive 110 rotolis, the extra ten covering any loss on transit and all other waste.
The next stage on the journey to Europe is from Omdurman to Khartoum North by boat, the cost of transit, including all other charges, varying from P.T. 1 to P.T. 2 (2 d to 6d) the cantar (99 lbs).

Prior to the opening of the railway between Khartoum and Port-Sudan, ile gum was carried either down the Nile by boat to Cairo, or by camels across the desert to Suakin, the time, taken in the latter case being 20 day, and the cost about PT 30 (6/1) the eantar but varying according to the supply of cainels. Now, however, the journey to Port-Sudan is done in about two days, the freight being P.T. 320 £3:5:8 the ton of 1000 kilograms. This figure is reduced by 10 % for consignments of ten tons.

From Port-Sudan the gum goes by steamer to Suez, where it is sometimes graded, and then either transhipped for Europe, America, or Australia as the case may be, or else sent on to Cairo or Alexandria by rail.
The principal markets for gum arabic are Marseilles, Havre, Hamburg, New-York, London, Liverpool, Antwerp, Barcelona, Melbourne, and Trieste.

The whole of the export trade is practically in the hands of Europeans, the shipping terms of payment being cash against documents, or from one to three months credit. In the case of a market like Melbourne, the buyer usually has a bank credit in London, upon which the seller is at liberty to draw.

The confectionery trade is perhaps the principal purchaser of gum arabic, though a very large number of other industries, e.g., chemical works, printing and dyeing mills, letter-press printers, and so on, are interested in this product of the Sudan.

At the present moment, the Sudan article experiences great competition from the Senegal gum, whilst in certain trades we understand that dextrine--a substance manufactured from the starch. extracted from the potato--replaces gum when the price of the latter is too high. (Journal of the British Chamber of Commerce.)

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN YORKSHIRE.
div.p: In the last year or two fine yarns made from Egyptian cotton have been used more freely outside Lancashire. In certain districts of Yorkshire, says the "Yorkshire Post, "a larger business has been done by Bolton producers of such yarns. Many new mills are now engaged on the finer numbers, and this increasing consumption has cleared the larger production of course Nottingham manufacturers are always, and especially now, extensive buyers.

div.head: ON BATTLEFIELD OF TEL EL KEBIR.
IMPORTANT MEETING OF I.O.G.T.
div.p: An I.O.GT. correspondent writes :--
On Thursday evening last an important session of the International Order of Good Templars was held at Kassasine, or as we may more historically term it, the great battlefield of Tel-el-Kebir.

At this spot, where our brave dead comrades sleep, the first G. sod Templary, meeting was held, a fitting commemoration to their dead comrades' glorious achievement in the suppression of the notorious rebel Osmap Digna. Here, too, on the morning in question, we fought a hard battle after a prolonged night march, and suppressed the enemy.

Amongst those present were :-- Inniskilling Excelsior Lodge, No. 109: Bros. O'Neill, Kerr, Jackson, Farr, Brown, Watkin, etc. Blae Caps Pride Lodge, No. 107: Bros. Ireland, Gervine, Hagan, etc. Hope of the Borderers: Bro. Townsend. The chair was occupied by Bro. Townsend, C. T. After the transaction of routine business the meeting proceeded, on "Good of Order." It was suggested, supported, and carried unanimously that we hold an amalgamated session at Cairo at an early date-date of meeting to be published in "Egyptian Gazette." The next item was a suggestion restricting members rejoining who had violated the obligation, unless they agreed to remain on probation for a period not exceeding 6 months. The views of the members may be summarized as follows:

The Order, through a violations and readmission, shall becqına as it were a laughing stock, and staunch members had, become 80 disgusted, that means must be resorted to in order to prevent the annihilation of the Order. These unprincipled men, backed by men who abhor the principles enunciated by Good Templars, are trying to ruin the cause, which means the resuscitation of the English race from degeneracy and ruin. " As representing Good Templary in Egypt it was resolved to forward a motion to Grand Lodge on the matter. The session was only closed at 9.20 p.m.

div.head: OBITUARY,
SIR THOS HANBURY, K.C.V.O.
div.p: The last papers from Rome. bring us the news of the death from influenza of Sir Thos Hanbury, KC.V.O., 80 well known as the creator and proprietor of the famous garden near the village of La Mortola, a mile or so from Ventimiglia, on the Western Riviera. He was born in 1832, and was brother of the distinguished pharmacologist, the late Daniel Bell Hanbury of Clapham, born in 1825, who joined at an early age the well known firm of pharmaceutical chemists, Allen, Barry and Co., who had succeeded Messrs. Bevanat Ploughcourt, Lombard-street, City. William Allen, F.R.S., F.L.S., the senior partner, was president of the Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain, which he had been mainly instrumental in founding, and a great philanthropist as well as scientist. He died in 1843 at Lindfield, in Sussex, where he had established schools, workshops, and playgrounds for both sexes. Daniel Hanbury took a great interest in the botanical determination of the sources of obscure vegetable drugs, and, since 1850, published numerous papers on the subject. In 1855 he was elected F.L.S.; in 1857 be became treasurer of the Linnean Society; and, in 1861, F.R.S. He died in 1876 at his residence at Clapham, after greatly contributing to our knowledge of Chinese medicinal and economic plants by examining and describing the vegetable products, transmitted to bim by his brother Thomas, now just deceased. The latter was a merchant at Shanghai from 1853 to 1871, and purchased the estate of the Orengo family of Ventimiglia, then an olive grove, with the "Palazzo" of that name as a residence, in 1866. He created the celebrated garden, now existing, assisted by his brother Daniel. A year before his death the latter had published, in 1874, in conjunction with Professor F. A. Flückiger of Strassburg University, a learned and valuable work called "Pharmacographia, or a History of the Principal Drugs of Vegetable Origin in Great Britain and British India," the historical information in which is due to Hanbury. A gevond edition was published in 1879, and a French one in 1878, with notes by Dr. J. L. de Lanessan of Paris. A year after his Heath Daniel Hanbury's scientific papers were collected and published by Mr Joseph Ince, in 1879, and a French one in 1878, with notes by Dr. J. L. de Lanessan of Paris. A year after his death Daniel Hanbury's scientific papers were collected and published by Mr Joseph Ince, in 1876, and his fine herbariun of 610 species of plants is now in possession of the Pharmaceutical Society, which published a catalogue of them in 1892 His name was immortalised in that of a new genus of Mexican C curbitaceae (Hanburia) in 1858, and a selection of sixty of the most important volume of his botanical library was presented to Kew by his brother, the late Sir Thom-18, in 1893. The latter was a great benefactor to the neighbourhood of Ventimiglia, to which he had presented a library and museum, and, quite recently, gave £2,000 towards the creation of a public garden there. He, also, presented the University of Genoa with a Botanical Institute inaugurated at the International Botanical Congress of 1892. His garden at La Mortola, covering nearly 100 acres, has long been celebrated as having the finest collection of soclinatized plants from all quarters of the globe in existence, in spite of the great dryness of the climate, there being only about forty rainy days in winter and two hundred cloudless ones in the year. The catalogue of 1889 gives the number of plants in the garden as 3,600, but many additions have since been made, and the possibilities of acclimatization are marvellously exemplified, The pretty rose-coloured acacia (albizzia julibrissin), so familiar on the shores of the Adriatic in July, flourishes here to perfection, and it is surprising that this elegant tree with fern-like foliage should still be absent from Alexandrian gardens.

div.head: GORDON CUP POLO TOURNAMENT.
div.p: The first match of the tournament was played before a large gathering of spectators on Monday afternoon, the opposing teams being as follows :
Inniskilling Dragoons I. (SCRATCH). Mr W. Holland 1 ,, Bowen II. Major Paterson III. ,, Haig back)
K.O.S.B. A + 10 GOALS. Mr. Furber. Capt. Kennedy. Major Stevenson. Capt. Stoney (back).

The Dragoons started 10 goals to the bad and made very little headway the first chukker. The K.O.S B. team played a keen and combined game. It was only just as the bell sounded that the Dragons scored their first goal. In the 2nd chukker, the Dragoons came away and scored a goal in the first minute. Then they spent four minutes hitting on both sides of the goal posts, but always just failing to hit through. They eventually succeeded and quickly followed this up with another, the score at half-time being : Dragoons, 4 goals ; K.O.S.B., 10 goals. Left with 16 minutes play to make 6 goals the Dragoons pressed hard, but their same bad luck attended them, their shots at goal being singularly unfortunate, and at the call of time they were still 8 goals to the bad. - To start 10 goals behind is a big undertaking, but with any luck the Dragoons would have won. At the same time the K.O.S.B. team played very well and pluckily, and they are to be congratulated on their win Score : Dragoons, 7 goals ; K.O.S.B., 10 goals.
2ND MATCH.
Egyptian Army. + 3 GOALS. Capt Gordon II. Capt. Amery I. Major Gillson III. Capt. Rome, (back).
Inniskilling Dragoons II. + 7 GOALS. Mr. Eleury Tealon. Mr. Merriman. Mr. Mixon. Capt. Holland.

The Dragoons' second team played an unexpectedly sound game. The E. A. team failed to find a proper combination. The match was a level one, only one goal being the difference at the call of time. The Dragoons' 2nd team started 4 goals up, this being the difference between the handicap. - At the call of time the scores were : E. A., 4 goals ; Dragoons 2nd team, 5 goals.
3RD MATCH. Tourists. (+ 5 GOALS) Mr. Vandeleur I. Mr. Ogilby II. Mr. de Preville III. Mr. Marsham, back
Staff and Departmental. (SCRATCH) Capt Hadow I. Capt. Dunbar II. Capt. Bartlett III. Mr. Jenkinson (back).

Major Pirie was away, so Mr. Marsham took his place. The Tourists started 5 goals up, and very soon added another goal to their score. The Staff, however, soon got together and some brilliant shots by Captains Dunbar and Bartlett resulted in several goals. At the beginning of the last chukker the game was 6 all. One more was soon added by the Staff, thug winning by one goal.
Three matches will be played on Wednesday.

div.head: BANQUE DU CAIRE, LIMITED,
div.p: Societe Anonyme par actions, constituée conformement aux Loie Anglaises Companies Acts 1862 a 1900
CAPITAL: Lstg. 600,000.
DIVISE EN 149.825 Actions ordinaires de Lstg. 4 chacune .... Lstg. 599,300 14.000 Parts de Fondateur ou aotions diffrees de 1 Shilling ,, 700 Lstg. 600,000

Les bénéfices de la Banque faits an cours de l'année financière ou de toute autre période comprise dans les comptes soumis a l'assemblée générale de chaque année, ainsi que tous les bénéfices reportés des années précédentes seront répartis par ordre de priorité comme soit:
1° 5% seront versés à un fonds de réserve à constituer jusqu'à concurrence d'un montant équivalent au quart du Capital.
2° Sur l'excédent, il sera pavé aux actions ordinaires un dividende cumulatif de 5% l'an sur le Capital versé sur les. dites actions.

3° Du surplus 60 % seront appliqués au paiement d'un dividende supplémentaire sur capital versé sur les dites actions ordinaires ou a la reserve ou autrement selon qu'il sera déterminé par la Société en Assemblée General et:
4° 40% seront répartis au prorata entre les porteurs de Parts de Fondateur
En cas de liquidation tout surplus relatif de l'actif sur le passif aprè* remboursement du Capital, sera, réparti comme suit:
60% au porteurs d'actions ordinaires. 40% aux Parts de fondateur.
Emission de 149 826 actions ordinaires et 14,000 Part» de fondateur dont 50,000 actions ordinaires et 500 PARTS DE FONDATEUR sout offertes à la souscription publique payables comme suit :
Actions Ordinaires : Dix shilling par action a la souscription Dix shillings par action a la repartition.
Et le solde sera appelé au fur et à mesure des besoins de la Banque à des intervalles non moindres de deux mois et par des versements non supérieurs à Jst. 1 par action.
Parts de Fondateur : Un Shilling a la souscription.
Pour chaque Cent actions allouées, sans tenir compte des fractions, il sera délivré une part de fondateur à un shilling, payable au pair.
Les 99,825 actions ordinaires et 13.500 parts de fondateurs qui restent ont été souscrites au pair par le Syndicat de garantie mentionné ci-après.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS.
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them Bre fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, aid possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than any other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to On leaving Egypt is Sicily. Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio Rubattino Co's steamers, which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is m chto interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic renmates that are found all over the island, are an endless source of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in BC 212, when Archimedes was slain--his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pas au temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city he Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Erimiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria, every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay-Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento (you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where all other week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excurssions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade. In Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallum brosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from. Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cogwheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO, One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY.
GENOA (La Superba).
div.p: - The most I picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities, and a phenomenally equable temperature- warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble calumns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santa filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and-a-half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on as count of its thermal springs, change trains at Bergo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P. & 0. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste-Vienna express from Alexandria As regarde heavy legge, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and
The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Vilan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass & quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at. every turn. The approach the Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other seaport. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon. Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes. COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in olie-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza: Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting CERNOBBIO is a charming spot.; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio- opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs." LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como, and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Aro nd it rise M San Salvatore, M. de Caprino and M. Generoso. LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and "The Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion. LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps. In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous. The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg ner ding a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature. BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse. THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds ; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concerts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc. "THE BERNESE OBERLAND.— INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort, and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaker is also not får from the famous" waterfalls, Gieselbach. Trummelbach and Staubbach Then also the glaciers of (Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed. CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft. above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, suarounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter. ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully situated on the lake of Zurich Theatres." Big Concert Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and Russian Steam Navigation Co. If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter. Tuesday festival held at Megara. for which a special train is run from Athens. It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery There is also good snipe and quaıl shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE of LUCERNE
Palace & Grand Hotel Axen-Fels. WORLD WIDE REPUTATION.
div.p: The Leading Hotel for English and American families. Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The magnificent Park and Woods have nearly a mile frontage on the Lake. Best Spring Resort. 2200 feet above the Sea, Every Comfort, level Wooded Walks.

mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay. These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry boats," having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: VENICE.
div.p: LIDO (Venice) VENICE charming trip on the lagoon, From Venice or Lido, 12 min. by steamboat CLIMATIC STATION AND SEA BATH, WITH CHINESITHERAPIC INSTITUTE. Express between the station and Lido for the Hotels,
BAGNI LIDO (Venice) The most important bathing station in Italy. Café-Restaurant and terrace on the sea. Hydrotherapie Institute. Concerts daily. Frequented by the highest classes of society.
GRAND HOTEL DES BAINS. Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependencies & Chalets. 2 rooms & saloons. Electric light aqueduct. Every modern comfort. Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.

THE GRAND HOTEL, LIDO. Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel), in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes', walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the legune of Venice. Room Iron 3 lire, with board from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos. Very dry and safe air.
Address -- SOCIETE BAGNI, LIDO, VENICE, ITALY.

div.head: The Egypt and Levant Steamship COMPANY LIMITED.
div.p: NOTICE is hereby given that the First Ordinary General Meeting of the Egypt and Levant Steamship Company, Limited, will be held at the offices of Messrs. Carver Brothers and Co., Ltd., Rue de 1 Aucienne Bourse, 'Alexandria, on Monday the 25th day of March 1907 at 4 p.m, for the transaction of the following business :-
1. To receive and consider the adoption of - the Directors Report and Accounts for the period ending 31st January 1907.
2. To elect a Director.
3. To elect Auditors.
4. To declare a Dividend.
5. General business.

Bearers of Sharė Warrants desiring to vote at the above-mentioned meeting must, on or before the 20th day of March 1907, deposit such Share Warrants with th sir Baukera, obtaining a receipt for same for admission to meeting.
Dated the 14th day of March 1907.
By Order of the Board,
L. Des CLAYES,
Local Secretary.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement
div.p: OF THE
" Egyptian Gazette. "

The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share market, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, completa tabular forms of the Varions market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt. for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra) For Further particulars apply to the Manager the 'Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: Khedivial Mail Line.
div.p: The new 18-knot twin Borew S.S. 'Osmanieh, leaving Alexandria on the 28th March, will follow a special fast itinerary, reaching Piraeus (Athens) in 30 hours, Smyrna in 74 hours, and Constantinople in 24 hours, in connection with the Oriental Railway's daily express service for Vienna, Berlin, Paris and London.
Special arrangements will be made for part of the 7.30 a.m. Express train from Cairo to run direct alongside,

This vessel is most luxuriously appointed. with accommodation (mostly in 2. berth cabins on deck for 142 first class amid hips and 70 second class aft. Her public saloons are exceptionally spacious and attractive, an she is also fitted with a large cabines deluxe on the spar deck, and an "Imperial" private, suite on the promenade deck comprising sitting-room, lounge, bedroom, 2 cabins, bathroom, lavatory, etc., with private promenade deck above.
Photograph of the Vessel is on view at Thos. Cook & Son (Egypt), Ltd., ave at Hamburg, American Reise-Burean, Cairo. 29594-15A14
